name: Snowy Owl
description: Males can be distinguished from females not only by size but also by coloration. The male is smaller and almost entirely white, while the female has much more prominent dark markings.
spread_note: Northern parts of continents, reaching nearly the North Pole.
image_alt: Snowy Owl, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
proportions: Body length 33.5–43.5 cm, tail length 19.5–22.5 cm, wingspan 38.5–43.5 cm, weight 0.9–2.9 kg
attractions: It most often resides in open tundra with low shrubs, herbs, and mosses, but can also be found in heathlands, various wetland habitats, and among dunes. Its main food source is rodents, especially lemmings. Occasionally, it catches rabbits, hares, or bird chicks. During mating season, the male emits a deep hooting call. It nests on the ground, with the female alone incubating the eggs and feeding the chicks, while the male brings food and leaves it at the nest’s edge.
breeding: Snowy Owls were transited through Prague in large numbers in the 1950s as part of Moscow Zoocenter’s efforts. Breeding began in 1959, with the first chicks raised in 1978.
